articles.title: You Don’t Need 10,000 Steps—7,000 Is Enough
articles.description: A recent global review found that walking just 7,000 steps per day yields substantial health benefits—reducing the risk of heart disease, dementia, depression, and early death—nearly as much as 10,000 steps.
ways_to_achieve: Aim for a daily target of around 7,000 steps—easy to reach with walking to class or taking movement breaks.
Incorporate short activity bursts like stairs or quick walks between periods.
Track progress using a phone or wearable; small increases from sedentary days provide meaningful gains.
benefits: About 47% lower risk of death compared to very low step counts.
Better control over weight and metabolism.
More attainable and realistic fitness goal for students.

articles.title: Minimally Processed Home Cooking Doubles Weight-Loss Results
articles.description: A study published this week shows individuals who ate minimally processed, home-cooked meals lost twice as much weight over eight weeks compared to those on calorie-matched ultra‑processed diets.
ways_to_achieve: Choose meals that use whole ingredients—vegetables, lean proteins, grains—cooked from scratch.
Plan simple weekly meals and avoid ready-made snacks or foods with long ingredient lists.
Replace sugary drinks or packaged snacks with whole fruit, nuts, or water.
benefits: Twice the weight loss (2% body weight vs. 1%) in just 8 weeks.
Fewer cravings and more meal satisfaction.
Supports long-term healthy habits and better dietary awareness.

articles.title: Boost Brain Protection with MIND-Style Foods
articles.description: Health experts today recommend foods that support cognitive health and reduce Alzheimer’s risk. Emphasis is on MIND‑style patterns combining Mediterranean and DASH diet principles.
ways_to_achieve: Include berries, leafy greens, walnuts, fish (like salmon), olive oil, and beans regularly.
Follow MIND/Mediterranean meal patterns: plenty of plant-based foods, moderate fish/poultry, limited saturated fats.
Reduce processed foods and focus on whole, nutrient-dense meals.
benefits: Supports memory, neural communication, and brain resilience.
Reduces inflammation and oxidative stress linked to dementia.
May slow cognitive aging and preserve executive function.
Aligns with long-term protective dietary habits.

articles.title: Diversifying Plant-Based Foods Trumps ‘5‑a‑Day’
articles.description: New research suggests that consuming 11 distinct plant-based foods daily—like herbs, nuts, legumes, seeds, and vegetables—offers greater heart health benefits than simply eating five servings of fruits and vegetables.
ways_to_achieve: Aim for 11 different plant foods daily: fruits, veggies, legumes, whole grains, seeds, nuts, herbs.
Rotate choices each meal—e.g. spinach, lentils, chia seeds, almonds, olives, basil.
Use “plant diversity diaries” to track variety, not just quantity.
benefits: Better HDL cholesterol and lower cardiovascular risk.
Improved fiber intake and gut health.
Greater nutrient diversity and metabolic resilience.
Encourages broader culinary habits and balanced meals.
